questions.text: Explore how William Blake presents ideas and attitudes towards the poverty and suffering of children in ‘Holy Thursday’ (E) and make connections with one or two other poems from your collection.

introduction: The indicative content shows an integrated approach to AO2 and AO1 with additional guidance for AO3 and AO4.

body_sections.Lexis: Words associated with wealth, fruition, religion, poverty, misery, usury, fear, joy, song, sunshine, rain, thorns, neglect, hunger, shock, outrage.
body_sections.Voice: 3rd person, stanzas 1-3 continuous present tense, shifting to conditional future in stanza 4. Voice is censorious, using rhetorical questions and statements.
body_sections.sub_topic: Poetic and stylistic techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Rhyme and rhythm: Varying quatrains with stresses on significant words. Iambic vs trochaic switching. Stanza 4 uses spondees and iambs. Rhyme: Stanza 1 slant/full; stanza 2 breaks down; stanzas 3-4 strengthen.
body_sections.Form and structure: 4 quatrains, lines varying between 7 and 8 syllables. Stanza 1: Line 1 and 4 = 8; lines 2 and 3 = 7. Stanzas 2-4: lines 1-3 = 7; line 4 = 8. Enjambment only in stanza 3 line 3.
body_sections.Imagery and symbolism: Contrasts suffering children in a rich land. 'Cold and usurous hand' vs 'fruitful land'. 'Trembling song' suggests babies are 'reducd'. 'Eternal winter' in stanza 3; 'bleak and bare' fields mock 'rich and fruitful land'.
body_sections.Grammar and morphology: Stanzas 1-3 in continuous present tense. Rhetorical questions in stanzas 1 and 2. Stanza 1 is an extended sentence. Modal verb 'can' suggests impossibility of 'song of joy'. Anaphora in lines 1-3. Stanza 4 in conditional future.

points: Of the poems: 'Songs of Experience' poem foregrounding the bleak world and criticising institutions.
Of the wider literary/cultural: Social commentary on the plight of the poorest in society and corrupt institutions exploiters.
body_sections.sub_topic: Context (AO3)

points: Possible connections: 'Holy Thursday (I)', 'London', and 'Chimney Sweeper (E)' regarding presentation of creative processes and social conditions.
body_sections.sub_topic: Connections (AO4)

questions.marker_instruction: A higher level response (levels 4 to 6) will: AO2 Use poetic and stylistic analysis effectively to support a coherent interpretation; AO1 Use vocabulary and terminology effectively; AO3 Make telling use of relevant literary or other contexts; AO4 Make interesting and illuminating use of points of connection between poems. A lower level response (levels 1 to 3) will: AO2 Identify some examples of poetic and stylistic techniques; AO1 Use some terminology appropriately; AO3 Make some relevant but limited use of contexts; AO4 Make a few relevant points of connection.

questions.text: Explore how Emily Dickinson presents ideas and attitudes towards rituals of death in ‘I heard a Fly buzz’ (465) and make connections with one or two other poems from your collection.

introduction: The indicative content shows an integrated approach to AO2 and AO1 with additional guidance for AO3 and AO4.

body_sections.Lexis: Death, dying, storms, grief, mourning, flies, insects, buzzing, God, faith, legal processes, property, light, dark, apertures.
body_sections.sub_topic: Poetic and Stylistic Techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Voice and Tone: 1st person, near past tense reflection on death and afterlife. Matter of fact tone becoming uncertain. Bathetic dark humour in fly's 'uncertain, stumbling buzz'.
body_sections.Rhyme and Rhythm: No rhyme pattern except stanza 4 lines 2 and 4 ('me'/'see'). Mostly iambic rhythm disrupted by short lines/clauses. Spondee in stanza 3 line 1.
body_sections.Form and Structure: 4 quatrains with hyphens for clauses. 1 open-ended sentence using 8/6 hymn metre. Enjambment in stanzas 1 and 3.
body_sections.Imagery and Symbolism: Storm suggests 'heav[ing] grief'. 'Gathering firm' breaths suggest composure. Mourners reduced to 'Eyes' 'wrung dry'. 'The King' (God) placed centrally vs fly at start and end. Legal note with 'Will' and 'Sign[ing] away'.
body_sections.Grammar and Morphology: Hyphenated clauses, single syllable words. 'Stillness' repeated. 'Eyes' personified. Dropped verbs and nouns in stanza 2. 'Willed' is ambiguous (strength vs legal). 'Blue' (implied color) as standalone abstract noun. Anaphora in stanza 4.

points: Of the poems: Explores fears and preoccupations with death rituals.
Of the wider literary/cultural: Body of literature exploring death within Christian tradition.
body_sections.sub_topic: Context (AO3)

points: Possible connections: 'It was not Death for I Stood up' (510) and 'I felt a Funeral, in my Brain (280)' regarding presentation of fears.
body_sections.sub_topic: Connections (AO4)

questions.marker_instruction: Level descriptors for AO1, AO2, AO3, AO4 apply. Higher level: detailed critical analysis, excellent application of concepts, perceptive context understanding, excellent cross-text exploration.

questions.text: Explore how Seamus Heaney presents thoughts and feelings about a way of life under threat in ‘The Toome Road’ and make connections with one or two other poems in your collection.

body_sections.Form: Single 17 line stanza (extended sonnet). First section lines 1-10; first volta line 10; final shift 14-17. Line lengths vary 10-12 syllables. 10 syllable lines for farmland and historical sections suggest unity.
body_sections.Lexis: Irish landscape, nature, farming, conflict, soldiers, military vehicles, camouflage, bad news, messenger, chariots, history, classical landscapes.
body_sections.sub_topic: Poetic and Stylistic Techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Voice and Tone: 1st person near past 'eye witness' account. Use of 'I' in lines 1, 7, 10. Shifts from outrage to ownership, then panicked messenger, finally historical commentator linking soldiers to charioteers.
body_sections.Rhyme and Rhythm: Full rhyme in lines 1-2, 7/8, 9/10. Half rhymes 14/15 and 16/17. Internal rhyme in line 9. Rhythm shifts between iambic and trochaic; final 4 lines are iambs.
body_sections.Imagery and Symbolism: Tanks contrast with rural Irish farmland. 'Warble' associated with birds or parasitic 'warble fly'. Camouflage ('broken branches') and 'dormant guns' signal invasion. 'Omphalos' final reference asserts land's spirit.
body_sections.Grammar and Morphology: 6 extended sentences. Past progressive tense in first 3 sentences. Personal pronoun 'I' with delayed time. Asyndeton list of farmland features. Dative 'whom' and conditional 'should' increase panic. Alliteration in lines 11-12. Ellipsis in line 15.

points: Of the poems: Explores lifestyles threatened by war, nature, or childbirth.
Of the wider literary/cultural: Irish poetry on landscape vulnerability. Hints at 'the Troubles' and Irish history.
body_sections.sub_topic: Context (AO3)

points: Possible connections: 'Death of a Naturalist', 'Act of Union', and 'Mycaenae Lookout' regarding threatened ways of life.
body_sections.sub_topic: Connections (AO4)

questions.marker_instruction: Evaluation based on AO1, AO2, AO3, AO4 levels. Higher level requires effective analysis and interesting connections.

questions.text: Explore how Boland presents ideas and feelings about capturing a moment in time in ‘From the Painting Back from Market by Chardin’ and make connections with one or two other poems in your collection.

body_sections.Form: 3 stanza 'lento'. 2 quatrains/8 lines. Lengths 5-12 syllables. Lines 3 and 5 are shortest. Frequent enjambment and hemistich.
body_sections.Lexis: Painting, art, peasant life, market, shopping, household goods, domestic spaces, stasis, survival, uniqueness, distinction.
body_sections.Voice: 3rd person past tense narrative in stanzas 1-2. Artist 'he' fixes the moment. Stanza 2 line 6 shifts to 1st person reflection on omitted details.
body_sections.sub_topic: Poetic and Stylistic Techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Rhyme and Rhythm: No fixed rhythm; iambs, trochees, and dactyls. Pace governed by lists. Full rhymes on lines 1/4 and 6/8.
body_sections.Imagery and Symbolism: Everyday life and colours. Opening seagull colours. Black and white final simile. Paired imagery. Alliteration. Symbolism of tension between tangible and imagined details (e.g., love). Power of artist to edit. 'Linked' suggests survival chain.
body_sections.Grammar and Morphology: Stanza 1 has 2 past tense sentences; first is extended with hyphens. Chiasmus on line 2. Asyndetic shopping list in lines 6-7. Stanza 2 uses past tense list, then shifts to present tense 'I'. Colon signals paired ideas. Stanza 3 is 1 extended sentence using progressive past tense. Conjunction 'although' signals volta.

points: Of the poems: Explores lives/roles of women in household duties and art.
Of the wider literary/cultural: Tradition of poems exploring women and domesticity in art.
body_sections.sub_topic: Context (AO3)

points: Possible connections: 'Degas's Laundresses', 'Woman in Kitchen', and 'Object Lessons' regarding capturing moments in time.
body_sections.sub_topic: Connections (AO4)

questions.marker_instruction: Mark scheme levels for AO1-AO4 apply. Requires analysis of Boland's use of techniques and literary contexts.

questions.text: Explore how Carol Ann Duffy presents ideas and feelings about the intensity and desperation of love in ‘Answer’ and make connections with one or two other poems from your collection.

body_sections.Form: 5 stanzas of 6 lines. Each stanza is an extended multiple-claused sentence. No enjambment. First 4 stanzas have shortened first line (6-7 syllables). Final stanza has hemistiches with 'if' statements; shortened final line.
body_sections.Lexis: Body, anatomy, stone, fire, burning, heat, water, air, wind, touch, nursing, branding, affirmation.
body_sections.Voice: 1st person rhetorical declaration using future conditional tense. Emphatic conditions for love. Repeated second person 'you' and 'your'.
body_sections.sub_topic: Poetic and Stylistic Techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Rhyme and Rhythm: Lines begin with spondees ('if', 'your'). Stanza 3 has varied spondee counts. Insistent rhythm. Half rhyme in stanza 2 lines 4-5. Full rhyme in stanza 3 lines 3-4.
body_sections.Imagery and Symbolism: Loved one described as manifestations of elements. Dark references (e.g., 'dark lake nursing the drowned'). Simile in stanza 1 line 5. Extreme element depictions symbolise intense love. Repeated 'yes, yes' affirmation.
body_sections.Grammar and Morphology: Stanzas 1-4 open and close with conditional signifier 'if'. Subordinate clauses separated by commas. Repeated possessive 'your'. 'Yes' repeated twice at end of each stanza. Line 6 variants reverse element positioning.

points: Of the poems: Traces development and ending of a love affair.
Of the wider literary/cultural: Tradition of poems about intensity and desperation of being in love.
body_sections.sub_topic: Context (AO3)

points: Possible connections: 'You', 'Write', and 'Betrothal' regarding intensity of love.
body_sections.sub_topic: Connections (AO4)

questions.marker_instruction: AO1, AO2, AO3, AO4 assessed. Higher level response uses effective analysis and tells use of contexts.

questions.text: Explore how Jacob Sam La-Rose presents ideas and feelings about cultural identity in ‘Turning Darker Still’ and make connections with one or two other poems from your collection.

body_sections.Form: Epigram from 'The Invisible Man' precedes poem. 5 quatrains, line lengths 8-14 syllables. Some enjambment. Italics for direct address.
body_sections.Lexis: Travel, walking, desert, burning, sky, sun, scrutiny, spotlight, smiling, teeth, darkness, water, aridity.
body_sections.Voice: 3rd person continuous present tense allegorical narrative. 'Rider' on desert journey. Direct address in italics from unidentified speaker (possibly sky/sun).
body_sections.sub_topic: Poetic and Stylistic Techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Rhyme and Rhythm: No rhyme scheme. Short clauses and hemistiches create insistent rhythm. Flexible metre using trochees.
body_sections.Imagery and Symbolism: Epigram suggests chaotic journey and race/identity concerns. Mental/physical suffering. Desert journey punishment. Links with slavery. 'Air which rises in welts'. 'Laughing horizon' mocks him. Sun as 'spotlight' darkening him.
body_sections.Grammar and Morphology: Continuous present tense. Dropped articles and pronouns suggest growing invisibility/lack of control. Active verbs in lines 3-4. Rhetorical questions in stanza 2. Omitted verbs contract sentences. Final 3 sentences lack subject/verbs. 'Cracked' is a single word verb sentence.

points: Of the poems: From 'Breaking Silence' collection exploring cultural identity (Guyanese heritage/London growth).
Of the wider literary/cultural: Fits literary tradition exploring identities and historical influences vs modern experiences.
body_sections.sub_topic: Context (AO3)

points: Possible connections: 'Speechless II', 'Speechless III', and 'Magnitude' regarding cultural identity presentation.
body_sections.sub_topic: Connections (AO4)

questions.marker_instruction: AO1, AO2, AO3, AO4 assessed. Requires analysis of techniques and connections across texts.

questions.text: Explore how Shakespeare presents Cassio’s drunkenness in this extract from Othello.

introduction: Integrated approach to AO2 and AO1 with AO3 guidance.

body_sections.Lexis: Nationalities, drink/drunkenness, religion. Words: 'offend', 'honour', 'unworthy'. Low register: 'potting', 'swag-bellied', 'vomit'.
body_sections.Discourse: Iago's private soliloquy. Conversation between 'friends'. Address terms ('lieutenant', 'Gentlemen'). Iago yielding the floor to Cassio.
body_sections.sub_topic: Dramatic and Stylistic techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Form and structure: Passage development: Iago's soliloquy followed by drunkenness, songs, and exit. Switch from blank verse to prose. Song form (rhyme, rhythm).
body_sections.Dramatic techniques: Dramatic irony (audience knows Iago's intentions). Staging of drinking songs. Cassio's performance of drunkenness.
body_sections.Grammar and morphology: Repeated minor exclamations ('Some wine, boys!'). Imperatives ('Do not think...'). Significant declarative 'You must not think then that am drunk'. Parallel phrasing ('this is my right hand...').
body_sections.Figurative language and rhetorical featu: Imagery: 'as my young mistress' dog', 'flock of drunkards', 'my boat sails freely'. Symbolic 'King Stephen' song. Patterning/listing. Word play.

points: The dramatic context: Iago's plan to 'abuse' Cassio; Cassio's loss of 'reputation'.
Wider contexts: Iago as a villain; Renaissance attitudes to reputation/drink; social hierarchy significance.
body_sections.sub_topic: Literary, dramatic or other relevant contexts (AO3)

questions.marker_instruction: AO1, AO2, AO3 assessed. Higher level response effectively uses analysis to support interpretation and uses relevant dramatic context.

questions.text: Explore how Wilde presents the relationships between men and women in this extract from The Importance of Being Earnest.

body_sections.Discourse: Private exchange between upper-class women/men. Adjacency pairs (question/answer). Characteristically formal register. Non-naturalistic fluency. Terms of address ('Darling!').
body_sections.sub_topic: Dramatic and Stylistic techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Form and structure: Genre: social comedy, satire, farce. Fast-paced structure (forgiveness/resolution).
body_sections.Dramatic techniques: Stage directions/business (Gwendolen 'moving to Cecily'). alliance formation. Beating time with finger. Characters speaking together. Jack 'clasps' Algernon's hand. Non-naturalistic performance.
body_sections.Grammar and morphology: Complex sentences. Formal register. Repeated structures ('I am .... We are').
body_sections.Figurative language and rhetorical featu: Irony: 'men have moments of physical courage of which we women know absolutely nothing'. Truth/lies exploration. Metaphor: 'stamp of truth'. Hyperbole: 'this fearful ordeal' (christening). Epigrammatic style.

points: Dramatic context: Exposure of Jack/Algernon deceptions; Lady Bracknell's refusal to consent.
Wider contexts: Deception convention in comedy of manners; satire of aristocracy; Aestheticism ('style' over truth); fin de siècle culture.
body_sections.sub_topic: Literary, dramatic or other relevant contexts (AO3)

questions.marker_instruction: AO1, AO2, AO3 assessed. Markers should reward original but well-focused answers.

questions.text: Explore how Williams presents the relationship between Mitch and Blanche in this extract from A Streetcar Named Desire.

body_sections.Lexis: Contrasts: light/dark, magic/realism. Mitch's proper nouns vs Blanche's abstract vocabulary. Modal auxiliary 'ought'.
body_sections.Discourse: Private conversation of heightened emotion. Simulated naturalistic dialogue. Adjacency pairs. Blend of turn lengths.
body_sections.sub_topic: Dramatic and Stylistic techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Form and structure: Genre: melodrama. Build up to Blanche's admission of 'intimacies'. Mitch's confrontation. Key relationship moment.
body_sections.Dramatic techniques: Stage directions: Mitch tearing paper lantern, switching on light. Blanche covering face. Performance indications: '[fearfully]', '[stupidly]'.
body_sections.Grammar and morphology: Blanche's minor interrogatives ('Which light?'). Emphasised imperative 'Don't turn the light on!'. Minor sentence 'Magic!'. Simple sentences during confrontation.
body_sections.Figurative language and rhetorical featu: Symbolic lantern. Metaphor of the spider. Nursery rhyme reference. Mitch's informal idiom. Euphemism: 'intimacies with strangers'.

points: Dramatic context: Following Stanley's revelation (Scene 8); hope in Scene 6; climactic confrontation with Stanley.
Wider contexts: Attitudes towards class; attitudes towards women and sexuality.
body_sections.sub_topic: Literary, dramatic or other relevant contexts (AO3)

questions.marker_instruction: Assess AO1, AO2, AO3. High tariff questions require a single developed response.

questions.text: Explore how Friel presents the hedge-school in this extract from Translations.

body_sections.Lexis: Proper nouns of Baile Beag people. Formality contrasts ('bugger' vs 'derivation'). Latin vocabulary taught to students.
body_sections.Discourse: Asymmetrical transactional exchange (educational). Abrupt register changes. Classroom adjacency pairs. Topic control. Hugh's dominance. Names to nominate speakers.
body_sections.sub_topic: Dramatic and Stylistic techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Form and structure: Hugh using baptism to teach Latin/Greek. Humour. Significance of Bridget paying for lessons. Development of character Doalty. Hugh's authority.
body_sections.Dramatic techniques: Hedge-school setting. Stage directions: comic build-up to Hugh's entrance. Hugh's drinking ('large quantity' but not drunk). 'Brief pause' significance. Formal education vs Baile Beag community.
body_sections.Grammar and morphology: Simple/minor sentences. Sentence fragments (Doalty's struggle). Compound sentence at extract end.
body_sections.Figurative language and rhetorical featu: Symbolic 'ritual of naming'. Idioms: 'tip of my tongue'. Humour. Reference to Sophocles.

points: Dramatic context: Fate of hedge-school; harmony prior to English arrival; Donnelly twins; exploration of language and identity.
Wider contexts: Field Day Theatre Company; hedge-schools; rural poor in Ireland.
body_sections.sub_topic: Literary, dramatic or other relevant contexts (AO3)

questions.marker_instruction: AO1, AO2, AO3 marks awarded. Candidates answer one question from Section B.

questions.text: Explore how Wertenbaker presents the audition in this extract from Our Country’s Good.

body_sections.Discourse: Audition context (Ralph in authority). Adjacency pairs initiated by Ralph. Dabby's questions and interruptions. Register contrast ('Recruiting Officer' vs naturalistic characters). Address modes: 'Brenham', 'Bryant'.
body_sections.sub_topic: Dramatic and Stylistic techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Form and structure: Act 1 Scene 5: Ralph auditions parts for 'The Recruiting Officer'. Dabby speaks for Mary. Characters developed. Humorous commentary. Parallels between play and convicts' difficult lives.
body_sections.Dramatic techniques: Mary's misunderstanding while reading. Laughter and silence.
body_sections.Grammar and morphology: Syntax: Ralph's elliptical fragments (potentially comic). Dabby's interrogatives. Contrastingly complex sentences in the play-readings.
body_sections.Figurative language and rhetorical featu: Humour ('Twelve hundred pounds! It must be a comedy'). Blurring of distinctions between play and convict lives. Farquhar's play as parallel/contrast.

points: Dramatic context: Ralph's plan to put on the play; subsequent rehearsals; exploration of theater's importance.
Wider contexts: Wertenbaker's work with prisoners; workshop methods (Royal Court); Keneally's 'The Playmaker'; Restoration comedy.
body_sections.sub_topic: Literary, dramatic or other relevant contexts (AO3)

questions.marker_instruction: AO1, AO2, AO3 assessed. Marking should fairly reflect relevant knowledge and skills.

questions.text: Explore how Butterworth presents conflicts over parenting in this extract from Jerusalem.

body_sections.Discourse: Separated couple argument. Frequent interruptions. Dawn's direct questioning/control of topic (searching for drugs). Johnny's attempts to placate. Instructions to Marky.
body_sections.sub_topic: Dramatic and Stylistic techniques (AO2 and AO1)
body_sections.Form and structure: Argument between Johnny and Dawn over Marky. Broken promise. Dawn's concern about bullying/prison. Ends with criticism of Johnny's failure to 'move on'.
body_sections.Dramatic techniques: Marky's exit. Props: Dawn's watch. Developing conflict.
body_sections.Grammar and morphology: Syntax: minor/elliptical sentences imitating spontaneous speech. Suggestion of Dawn's anger. Johnny's imperatives.
body_sections.Figurative language and rhetorical featu: Imagery: the watch; world turning. Simile: 'needs that like a bag on his head'. Idiom: 'storm in a teacup'. Dawn's irony. Johnny's reduced stature.

points: Dramatic context: Police's impending arrival; subsequent kiss; significance of Marky; alternative perspective on Johnny's behavior.
Wider contexts: Naturalistic drama; Romany culture; drugs/criminality/youth culture.
body_sections.sub_topic: Literary, dramatic or other relevant contexts (AO3)

questions.marker_instruction: AO1, AO2, AO3 marks. Use lowest mark in level only if answer is borderline.
